2016 }}}} (born 6 December 1947) is a [[British people|British]]-[[Canadians|Canadian]] [[cognitive psychology|cognitive psychologist]] and [[computer scientist]], most noted for his work on [[artificial neural networks]]. Since 2013, he has divided his time working for [[Google]] ([[Google Brain]]) and the [[University of Toronto]]. In 2017, he co-founded and became the Chief Scientific Advisor of the [[Vector Institute (University of Toronto)|Vector Institute]] in Toronto.{{cite journal |journal=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |first=Daniela |last=Hernandez |title=The Man Behind the Google Brain: Andrew Ng and the Quest for the New AI |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2013/05/neuro-artificial-intelligence/all/ |date=7 May 2013 |access-date=10 May 2013 }}{{cite web |title=Geoffrey E. Hinton – Google AI |url=https://ai.google/research/people/GeoffreyHinton |website=Google AI |language=en}} With [[David Rumelhart]] and [[Ronald J. Williams]], Hinton was co-author of a highly cited paper published in 1986 that popularized the [[backpropagation]] algorithm for training multi-layer neural networks, although they were not the first to propose the approach. Hinton is viewed as a leading figure in the [[deep learning]] community.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/09/14/geoffrey-hinton-was-briefly-a-google-intern-in-2012-because-of-bureaucracy/|title=Geoffrey Hinton was briefly a Google intern in 2012 because of bureaucracy – challenge]] 2012{{Cite journal|last1=Krizhevsky|first1=Alex|last2=Sutskever|first2=Ilya|last3=Hinton|first3=Geoffrey E.|date=3 December 2012|title=ImageNet classification with deep convolutional on deep learning.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/turing-award-ai-deep-learning-1.5070415|title=Canadian researchers who taught AI to learn like humans win $1M award {{!}} CBC the "Godfathers of AI" and "Godfathers of Deep Learning",{{Cite web|last=Ranosa|first=Ted|date=2019-03-29|title=Godfathers Of AI Win This Year's Turing Award And $1 Million|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/240511/20190329/godfathers-of-ai-win-this-years-turing-award-and-1-million.htm|access-date=2020-11-05|website=Tech Times|language=en}}{{Cite give public talks together.{{Cite web|last=Ray|first=Tiernan|title=Nvidia's GTC will feature deep learning cabal of LeCun, Hinton, and Bengio|url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/nvidias-gtc-will-feature-deep-learning-cabal-of-lecun-hinton-bengio/|access-date=2021-04-07|website=ZDNet|language=en}}{{cite web |title=50 Years at CMU: The Inaugural Raj Reddy Artificial Intelligence Lecture |url=https://www.cs.cmu.edu/events/raj-reddy-50 |website=cs.cmu.edu |access-date=2 March 2022}} ==Education== Hinton was educated at [[King's College, Cambridge]], graduating in 1970 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in experimental psychology. He continued his study at the [[University of Edinburgh]] where he was awarded a [[PhD|Ph.D.]] in [[artificial intelligence]] in 1978 for research supervised by [[H. Christopher Longuet-Higgins|Christopher Longuet-Higgins]].{{cite thesis|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Edinburgh|title=Relaxation and its role in vision|first= Geoffrey Everest|last=Hinton|date=1977|id={{EThOS|uk.bl.ethos.482889}}|oclc=18656113|hdl=1842/8121}} {{free access}} ==Career and research== After his Ph.D., he worked at the [[University of Sussex]] and, (after difficulty finding funding in Britain), the [[University of California, San Diego]] and [[Carnegie Mellon University]]. He was the founding director of the [[Gatsby Charitable Foundation]] Computational Neuroscience Unit at [[University College London]] and {{as of |2001|alt=is currently}}https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/fullcv.pdf {{Bare URL PDF|date=March 2022}} a [[professor]] in the [[computer science]] department at the [[University of Toronto]]. He holds a [[Canada Research Chair]] in Machine Learning and is currently an advisor for the ''Learning in Machines & Brains'' program at the [[Canadian Institute for Advanced Research]]. Hinton taught a free online course on Neural Networks on the education platform [[Coursera]] in 2012.{{Cite web |url=https://www.coursera.org/learn/neural-networks |title=Archived copy |access-date=30 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231174321/https://www.coursera.org/learn/neural-networks |archive-date=31 December 2016 |url-status=dead }} Hinton joined [[Google]] in March 2013 when his company, DNNresearch Inc., was acquired. He is planning to "divide his time between his university research and his work at Google".{{cite press release|title=U of T neural networks start-up acquired by Google|date=12 March 2013|location=Toronto, ON|url=http://media.utoronto.ca/media-releases/u-of-t-neural-networks-start-up-acquired-by-google/|access-date=13 March 2013}} Hinton's research investigates ways of using neural networks for [[machine learning]], [[memory]], [[perception]] and symbol processing. He has authored or co-authored over 200 [[peer review]]ed publications.{{Google scholar id}}{{Scopus id}} At the Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeuRIPS) 2022, Hinton introduced a new learning algorithm for neural networks that he calls the "Forward-Forward" algorithm. The idea of the new algorithm is to replace the traditional forward-backward passes of backpropagation with two forward passes, one with positive (i.e. real) data and the other with negative data which could be generated by the network itself.{{cite press release|title=The Forward-Forward Algorithm: Some Preliminary Investigations|location=Toronto, ON|url=https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/FFA13.pdf}} While Hinton was a professor at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] (1982–1987), [[David E. Rumelhart]] and Hinton and [[Ronald J. Williams]] applied the [[Backpropagation|backpropagation algorithm]] to multi-layer neural networks. Their experiments showed that such networks can learn useful [[Knowledge representation|internal representations]] of data.{{Cite journal|last1=Rumelhart|first1=David E.|last2=Hinton|first2=Geoffrey E.|last3=Williams|first3=Ronald J.|date=9 October 1986|title=Learning representations by back-propagating errors|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=323|issue=6088|pages=533–536|doi=10.1038/323533a0|issn=1476-4687|bibcode=1986Natur.323..533R|s2cid=205001834}} In an interview of 2018,{{cite book|first=Martin |last=Ford|title=Architects of Intelligence: The truth about AI from the people building it|date=2018|publisher=Packt Publishing|isbn=978-1-78913-151-2}} Hinton said that "[[David E. Rumelhart]] came up with the basic idea of backpropagation, so it's his invention." Although this work was important in popularizing backpropagation, it was not the first to suggest the approach.{{Cite journal|date=2015-01-01|title=Deep learning in neural networks: An overview|journal=Neural Networks|volume=61|pages=85–117|doi=10.1016/j.neunet.2014.09.003|pmid=25462637|last1=Schmidhuber|first1=Jürgen|arxiv=1404.7828|s2cid=11715509}} Reverse-mode [[automatic differentiation]], of which backpropagation is a special case, was proposed by [[Seppo Linnainmaa]] in 1970, and [[Paul Werbos]] proposed to use it to train neural networks in 1974. During the same period, Hinton co-invented [[Boltzmann machine]]s with David Ackley and [[Terry Sejnowski]].Ackley, David H; Hinton Geoffrey E; Sejnowski, Terrence J (1985), "A learning algorithm for Boltzmann machines", Cognitive science, Elsevier, 9 (1): 147–169 His other contributions to neural network research include [[distributed representation]]s, [[time delay neural network]], mixtures of experts, [[Helmholtz machines]] and [[Product of Experts]]. In 2007 Hinton coauthored an [[unsupervised learning]] paper titled ''Unsupervised learning of image transformations''.{{cite web | url = http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/papers.html | title = Geoffrey E. Hinton's Publications in Reverse Chronological Order | last = Hinton | first = Geoffrey E. }} An accessible introduction to Geoffrey Hinton's research can be found in his articles in ''[[Scientific American]]'' in September 1992 and October 1993.{{cite web | url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/author/geoffrey-e-hinton/ | title = Stories by Geoffrey E. Hinton in Scientific American| website = [[Scientific American]]}} In October and November 2017 respectively, Hinton published two [[open access]] research papersSabour, Sara; Frosst, Nicholas; Hinton, Geoffrey. October 2017. [https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.09829 "Dynamic Routing Between Capsules"][https://openreview.net/forum?id=HJWLfGWRb¬eId=HJWLfGWRb "Matrix capsules with EM routing"] 3 November 2017. OpenReview.net on the theme of [[capsule neural network]]s, which according to Hinton are "finally something that works well."Geib, Claudia. 2 November 2017. [https://futurism.com/weve-finally-created-an-ai-network-thats-been-decades-in-the-making/ "We’ve Finally Created an AI Network That’s Been Decades in the Making"] Futurism.com Notable former PhD students and [[postdoctoral research]]ers from his group include [[Peter Dayan]],{{cite web|publisher=Geoffrey Hinton|title=Geoffrey Hinton's postdocs|url=http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/postdocs.html}} Sam Roweis, [[Max Welling]], [[Richard Zemel]], [[Brendan Frey]], [[Radford M. Neal]], [[Yee Whye Teh]], [[Ruslan Salakhutdinov]], [[Ilya Sutskever]], [[Yann LeCun]],{{Cite web|url=http://yann.lecun.com/ex/research/index.html|title=Yann LeCun's Research and Contributions|website=yann.lecun.com|access-date=13 March 2018}} [[Alex Graves (computer scientist)|Alex Graves]], and [[Zoubin Ghahramani]]. ===Honours and awards=== [[File:Deep Thinkers on Deep Learning.jpg|thumb|right|From left to right [[Russ Salakhutdinov]], [[Richard S. Sutton]], Geoffrey Hinton, [[Yoshua Bengio]] and [[Steve Jurvetson]] in 2016]] Hinton was elected a [[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 1998|Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 1998]]. He was the first winner of the [[Rumelhart Prize]] in 2001.{{cite web |url=http://rumelhartprize.org/?page_id=12 |title=Current and Previous Recipients |publisher=David E. Rumelhart Prize |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302000053/http://rumelhartprize.org/?page_id=12 |archive-date=2 March 2017 |url-status=dead }} His certificate of election for the Royal Society reads: {{centered pull quote|Geoffrey E. Hinton is internationally distinguished for his work on artificial neural nets, especially how they can be designed to learn without the aid of a human teacher. This may well be the start of autonomous intelligent brain-like machines. He has compared effects of brain damage with effects of losses in such a net, and found striking similarities with human impairment, such as for recognition of names and losses of categorization. His work includes studies of mental imagery, and inventing puzzles for testing originality and creative intelligence. It is conceptual, mathematically sophisticated and experimental. He brings these skills together with striking effect to produce important work of great interest.{{cite web |url=https://collections.royalsociety.org/DServe.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=show.tcl&dsqSearch=(RefNo==%27EC%2F1998%2F21%27) |title=Certificate of election EC/1998/21: Geoffrey Everest Hinton |publisher=[[Royal Society]] |archive-date=5 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505114828/https://collections.royalsociety.org/DServe.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=show.tcl&dsqSearch=(RefNo==%27EC%2F1998%2F21%27) |location=London |author=Anon |year=1998 |url-status=dead }}}} In 2001, Hinton was awarded an [[Honorary Doctorate]] from the [[University of Edinburgh]].{{cite news|title=Distinguished Edinburgh graduate receives ACM A.M. Turing Award|newspaper=The University of Edinburgh|url=https://www.ed.ac.uk/informatics/news-events/stories/2019/distinguished-edinburgh-graduate-receives-acm-tur|access-date=April 9, 2019}} He was the 2005 recipient of the [[IJCAI Award for Research Excellence]] lifetime-achievement award.{{Cite web|title=IJCAI Awards {{!}} IJCAI|url=https://www.ijcai.org/awards|access-date=2021-08-05|website=www.ijcai.org}} He has also been awarded the 2011 [[Gerhard Herzberg Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering|Herzberg Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering]].{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2011/02/14/science-herzberg-hinton-artificial-intelligence.html#ixzz1DxUEvAcQ | work=CBC News | title=Artificial intelligence scientist gets M prize | date=14 February 2011}} In 2013, Hinton was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from the [[Université de Sherbrooke]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usherbrooke.ca/actualites/relations-medias/communiques/communiques-details/c/24638/|title=Geoffrey Hinton, keystone researcher in artificial intelligence, visits the Université de Sherbrooke|publisher=[[Université de Sherbrooke]]|date=19 February 2014}} In 2016, he was elected a foreign member of [[National Academy of Engineering]] "For contributions to the theory and practice of artificial neural networks and their application to speech recognition and computer vision".{{cite web |url=https://www.nae.edu/Projects/MediaRoom/20095/149240/149788.aspx |title=National Academy of Engineering Elects 80 Members and 22 Foreign Members |date=8 February 2016 |publisher=NAE }} He also received the 2016 [[IEEE/RSE Wolfson James Clerk Maxwell Award]].{{cite web|title=2016 IEEE Medals and Recognitions Recipients and Citations|url=https://www.ieee.org/about/awards/2016_ieee_medal_and_recognition_recipients_and_citations_list.pdf|publisher=[[IEEE]]|access-date={{Format date|2016|07|07}}}} He has won the [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] (2016) in the Information and Communication Technologies category "for his pioneering and highly influential work" to endow machines with the ability to learn.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbva.com/en/bbva-foundation-bestows-award-architect-first-machines-capable-learning-way-people/|title=The BBVA Foundation bestows its award on the architect of the first machines capable of learning the way people do|date=17 January 2017|publisher=BBVA Foundation}} Together with [[Yann LeCun]], and [[Yoshua Bengio]], Hinton won the 2018 [[Turing Award]] for conceptual and engineering breakthroughs that have made deep neural networks a critical component of computing.{{cite web |url=https://vectorinstitute.ai/2019/03/27/vector-institutes-chief-scientific-advisor-dr-geoffrey-hinton-receives-acm-a-m-turing-award-alongside-dr-yoshua-bengio-and-dr-yann-lecun/ |title=Vector Institutes Chief Scientific Advisor Dr.Geoffrey Hinton Receives ACM A.M. Turing Award Alongside Dr.Yoshua Bengio and Dr.Yann Lecun |date=27 March 2019 |publisher=NAE }}{{cite news |title=Three Pioneers in Artificial Intelligence Win Turing Award |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/27/technology/turing-award-hinton-lecun-bengio.html |access-date=27 March 2019 |work=[[New York Times]] |date=27 March 2019}}{{cite web |title= Fathers of the Deep Learning Revolution Receive ACM A.M. Turing Award - Bengio, Hinton and LeCun Ushered in Major Breakthroughs in Artificial Intelligence |url= https://www.acm.org/media-center/2019/march/turing-award-2018 |access-date=27 March 2019 |work=[[Association for Computing Machinery]] |date=27 March 2019}} In 2018, he was awarded a Companion of the [[Order of Canada]].{{cite web|url=https://www.gg.ca/en/media/news/2018/governor-general-announces-103-new-appointments-order-canada|title=Governor General Announces 103 New Appointments to the Order of Canada, December 2018.|date=21 December 2018|access-date=7 June 2020|archive-date=19 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191119172458/https://www.gg.ca/en/media/news/2018/governor-general-announces-103-new-appointments-order-canada|url-status=dead}} In 2022 he received the [[Princess of Asturias Awards|Princess of Asturias Award]] in the category "Scientific Research", along with [[Yann LeCun]], [[Yoshua Bengio]], and [[Demis Hassabis]].[https://www.fpa.es/en/princess-of-asturias-awards/laureates/2022-geoffrey-hinton-yann-lecun-yoshua-bengio-and-demis-hassabis.html?especifica=0&idCategoria=0&anio=2022&especifica=0 Princess of Asturias Awards 2022] ==Personal life== Hinton is the great-great-grandson of the mathematician and educator [[Mary Everest Boole]] and her husband, the logician [[George Boole]],{{Cite web|title=Geoffrey Hinton: The story of the British 'Godfather of AI' - who's not sat down since 2005|url=https://news.sky.com/story/the-story-of-the-british-godfather-of-ai-whos-not-sat-down-since-2005-12249571|access-date=2021-04-07|website=Sky News|language=en}} whose work eventually became one of the foundations of modern computer science. Another great-great-grandfather was the surgeon and author [[James Hinton (surgeon)|James Hinton]],[http://www.cse.buffalo.edu/~rapaport/111F04/boole.html The Isaac Newton of logic] who was the father of [[Charles Howard Hinton]]. Hinton's father was [[H. E. Hinton|Howard Hinton]].{{cite journal|last1=Salt|first1=George|title=Howard Everest Hinton. 24 August 1912-2 August 1977|journal=[[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]]|volume=24|year=1978|pages=150–182|issn=0080-4606|doi=10.1098/rsbm.1978.0006|title-link=H. E. Hinton|doi-access=free}} His middle name comes from another relative, [[George Everest]].{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Craig S.|title=The Man Who Helped Turn Toronto into a High-Tech Hotbed|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/23/world/canada/the-man-who-helped-turn-toronto-into-a-high-tech-hotbed.html|access-date=27 June 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 June 2017}} He is the nephew of the economist [[Colin Clark (economist)|Colin Clark]].{{cite news|last1=Shute|first1=Joe|title=The 'Godfather of AI' on making machines clever and whether robots really will learn to kill us all?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/08/26/godfather-ai-making-machines-clever-whether-robots-really-will/|access-date=20 December 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=26 August 2017}} He lost his second wife to ovarian cancer in 1994.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/08/26/godfather-ai-making-machines-clever-whether-robots-really-will/|title=The 'Godfather of AI' on making machines clever and whether robots really will learn to kill us all?|last1=Shute|first1=Joe|date=26 August 2017|work=The Telegraph|access-date=30 January 2018}} ===Views=== Hinton moved from the U.S. to Canada in part due to disillusionment with [[Ronald Reagan]]-era politics and disapproval of military funding of artificial intelligence. Hinton has petitioned against [[lethal autonomous weapon]]s. Regarding [[existential risk from advanced artificial intelligence|existential risk from artificial intelligence]], Hinton typically declines to make predictions more than five years into the future, noting that exponential progress makes the uncertainty too great. name="fogofprogress">{{cite web|last1=Hinton|first1=Geoffrey|title=Lecture 16d The fog of progress|url=https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~hinton/coursera/lecture16/lec16.pdf}} Hinton is optimistic about AI’s impact on the job market: “The phrase ‘artificial general intelligence’ carries with it the implication that this sort of single robot is suddenly going to be smarter than you. I don’t think it’s going to be that. I think more and more of the routine things we do are going to be replaced by AI systems — like the Google Assistant.” {{cite web |title=Geoffrey Hinton and Demis Hassabis: AGI is nowhere close to being a reality |url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/12/17/geoffrey-hinton-and-demis-hassabis-agi-is-nowhere-close-to-being-a-reality/ |website=venturebeat|date=17 December 2018 }} Hinton argues that AGI won’t make humans redundant. Rather, he says, it will remain for the most part myopic in its understanding of the world — at least in the near future. He believes that it’ll continue to improve our lives in small but meaningful ways. “[AI in the future is] going to know a lot about what you’re probably going to want to do and how to do it, and it’s going to be very helpful. But it’s not going to replace you,” he said. “If you took [a] system that was developed to be able to be very good [at driving], and you sent it on its first date, I think it would be a disaster.” And for dangerous tasks currently performed by humans, that’s a step in the right direction, according to Hinton. {{cite web |title=Geoffrey Hinton and Demis Hassabis: AGI is nowhere close to being a reality |url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/12/17/geoffrey-hinton-and-demis-hassabis-agi-is-nowhere-close-to-being-a-reality/ |website=venturebeat|date=17 December 2018 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{wikiquote}} {{Scholia|author}} {{FRS 1998}} {{Turing Award laureates}} {{Princess of Asturias Award for Technical and Scientific Research}} {{Differentiable computing}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hinton, Geoffrey}} [[Category:Artificial intelligence researchers]] [[Category:British computer scientists]] [[Category:Canadian computer scientists]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:Fellows of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Google employees]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Machine learning researchers]] [[Category:University of Toronto faculty]] [[Category:Canada Research Chairs]] [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University faculty]] [[Category:Rumelhart Prize laureates]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Fellows of the Cognitive Science Society]] [[Category:Turing Award laureates]] [[Category:People from Wimbledon, London]] [[Category:Foreign associates of the National Academy of Engineering]] [[Category:Hinton family]] [[Category:Canadian Fellows of the Royal Society]]
